review_title: Learning a lot of new things
pros: - Bosses are always looking to improve current processes. - There's lots of opportunities to advance and showcase your attributes as a performer as there's always one project or another going on. - Get to learn new things as there are a lot of systems/legislations due to different entities in different regions. Company also encourages internal transfers and rotations.
cons: - High turnover. Need to work and re-work current processes as steps keep getting lost due to the change in staff. - Will need patience to learn different systems and how things work for different entities in different regions.

pros: Most colleagues are pleasant. Work is not highly stressful.
cons: Highly obvious favoritism is noticeable towards star players. Star players in turn have a "stuck-up" attitude and spend most of their work hours either sucking up to management or focused on activities which give can improve their presence. Regular employees have a questionable existence (ignored by senior colleagues and managers) and can definitely forget about career progression, which is locked behind many layers of unknown criteria. Company level goals, when cascaded down to the individual employee do not serve as a promotion checklist.

pros: As for me, the work shift pattern is good, which is 2 days work and 2 days off with 12 hours shift. Friendly and supportive colleagues, transport provided at various pickup points. The working environment is okay, IQAs are required to be independent. You have to be a fast leaner in order to catch up a lot of things. This position more or less will train you in the communication aspect, which requires you to communicate with other people from various departments. Lots of benefits.
cons: The trainings and learnings were assigned to me without proper guidance, so I was a bit lost at first. Even the face scanning registration was done a bit late. Took quite long to get my ID card. In term of allowances, no housing allowance, and shift allowance is quite low.

review_title: Company that cares about its employees

The company managed to use the threat of the pandemic and turned it into an big opportunity. This in turn brought huge upsides in revenue for the company, and the company has been willing to distribute the pandemic bonus to the employees.

During the pandemic, the company takes pain to care about its employees. Constant engaging with the employees on how you are coping during the pandemic.
cons:
In the site I am at, there are still alot of paper work. Electronic records are still not widely adopted.

No fixed change management practices. But this present the opportunities to turn it around.

review_title: Great culture and Tone at the top
pros:
- Company is moving in right direction by having employee surveys, monetary rewards for hard work and taking employees' performance reviews seriously (i.e. not just a paper exercise)
- Open and honest environment. It feels that the Company is genuinely trying to share as much information on initiatives, operations, financial results as possible to the employees through many townhalls.
- Lots of emphasis and initiatives over employee's mental health and belonging.
- Diversity is practiced, not just preached. 
- Experienced colleagues are relatively friendly and sincere in helping to explain and guide through the complexity of the organisation
- I was blessed with a great bosses who invests time and effort in coaching and guiding me especially during the initial period. Giving timely and straightforward feedback without having to second guess any 'underlying' meaning really makes it easier to work for them. 
- Many opportunities within the finance function which will allow for career growth and development
cons:
- No opportunity to slack
- Huge and highly complex organisation with pockets of manual processes

review_title: Variety of Career Opportunity with Positive Impact on Society
pros:
Thermo Fisher Scientific is a company with a wide variety of business units in the life science industry.
Hence there is a variety of opportunities for talent to grow their career vertically or horizontally. 
The job that we do has a direct positive impact on the society and you will have a great sense of satisfaction.
For example, during the COVID-19 pandemic, our products assist in the research & diagnose of COVID-19. We also provide bioprocessing tools and solutions for vaccine development and production.
Hence I'm very proud to be part of Thermo Fisher Scientific family to enable our customers to make the world healthier, cleaner, and safer.

review_title: Good pay and benefits are dwarfed by toxic culture.
pros: Salary when hired is competitive, but after that, don’t expect financial growth unless you switch roles on a regular basis. Annual raises don’t even outpace inflation. Benefits are very good. If you can make your way into a corporate role, you’ll be riding the gravy train.
cons: Site level roles are less desirable, and unless you make your way into the good graces of the leadership “clique,” you will stay stagnant. Management culture is extremely toxic, comprised mostly of a group of gossipy, power hungry people who will step on those beneath them to boost their own situations. The hierarchy is despicable in many ways, and direct labor employees are treated like “less than thou”. As a result, direct labor employees are mostly negative in mindset. As a manufacturing engineer who works with DL staff every day, it can be extremely tolling to constantly hear the woes of the DL staff, only for those woes to fall on deaf ears with leadership. Also, whatever capital is secured at the site level is quickly squandered by the leadership team on initiatives they deem important for their own well being, so meaningful capital projects are few and far between.

pros: No company is perfect, but almost everyone I’ve worked with over the course of my time here has gone out of their way to help me any time I had a question or concern. Their benefits are great, especially their Appreciate program, which allows employees to recognize their peers; I’ve never had that before. At previous companies, only executives had the privilege, so it was all about who you know. At Thermo, supervisors are encouraged to advance their subordinates careers; this is typically part of their annual goals (at least my division) so there is opportunity for growth and constant conversation around your career next steps.
cons: I work remote, so I don’t experience too many cons. If any – and I’m reaching – maybe that because of the level of oversight for remote employees, some don’t pull their weight as much as others? But their lack of work is apparent in their numbers at the end of the year, so it doesn’t typically have a huge impact on me.

job_title: Maintenance Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: Large stable company Room for growth
cons: • Thermo Fisher uses the term, "at will employment" loosely and regularly excercises extreme measures to unfairly discipline, or in most cases, terminate their employees. • An unsubstantiated claim by another employee is enough to get another employee terminated. Many that work there know this and use it to get other coworkers terminated. This has created a toxic environment that Thermo Fisher's headquarter HR department fully endorses. Investigations of accusations typically go in favor of the accuser unless there is substantial evidence to the contrary. In other words, guilty until proven innocent. Since employees are hired on an "at will" basis, investigations are done poorly, without follow up. HR investigators, even ones at Senior Management level do not investigate to find out the truth, they investigate strictly in risk managemnent fashion. In other words, they investigate biasedly in favor of which ever side takes action to successfully intimidate their HR department with potential lawsuites, even if the lawsuites would be far fetched. I repeat, investigations are unfair and biased strictly based on risk management regardless of the truth. Thermo Fisher Scientific is so bold in doing this, they don't even try and hide it. Because it's technically not against the law, ethics go right out the window to the point of abusing and misusing the "at will" policy that strictly protects employers. Thermo Fishers Scientific's HR (Human Resources) does not perform their job properly and only gives the appearance of performing investigations to insure their "risk management" approach isn't grossly being mishandled. • Thermo Fisher Scientific fully embraces the concept of, "you're just a number" is ingrained into the culture provideing a very toxic environment in departments with less than superior management talent. No management is perfect, so HR, for the most part, throws their weight around, abuses their positions as HR representatives.

review_title: Waste of professional experience and development
pros: Quick hiring process and bi weekly check
cons: I was catfished by TFS recruitment in Hillsboro, OR . Not only did I not get 90 days of training promised or field work that involves travel, but there were no developmental opportunities given. You will have the same conversations about it and nothing will be improved. You may run into a situation where you will not be included and still be expected to do all the heavy lifting in the work relationships. I do not trust my direct manager at all because they are unable to keep things confidential and it’s very obvious that the manager is controlling and pulling strings behind the scenes. The manager is easy manipulated and pulled in many directions and will project all that on you then come to you with the latest gossip or group feelings. It’s very unsettling and I hate when managers do that because this leads to so many more issues between coworkers and attracts the wrong people to become involved in the work. Likewise many of the inexperienced new hires straight from grad school have a very egotistical and selfish attitude and will try to stop you from receiving recognition for your work by inserting themselves into your business and taking over projects. They will not acknowledge your work, take credit for it, and will not work with you. All these behaviors are overlooked by the group as a whole because it’s the culture to scheme to get the chosen ones in place. And these Coworkers are very nosy and seek constant validation. This place is not the ideal working situation because coworkers are mirco managing each other too and overwork themselves instead of sharing the responsibility. The smart ones try to avoid it but the crabs in the barrel will keep trying to pull you down back into the toxicity. The insecure coworkers will work against you to appear more equipped and efficient at their job but it’s not true. They will go behind your back.

review_title: Toxic work environment, discrimination and low wages
job_title: Pick and Packer in Weil am Rhein
pros: Free coffee machine and hot chocolate
cons: 1) All the supervisor i encountered with are talking down to employees all the time and there's constant pressure created by the supervisor, with no practical reason at all. As a result, even if you go to toilet or pouring a glass of water, it's expected from you, to give a full-report, where you at, even if there's literally no work to do. 2) Thermo Fisher Germany decided to make their corporate language, German and English, so the worker are prohibited to speak in another language while working. Around half of the staff are French background. As I noticed personally, but was told by other co-workers too, worker with French background speak all the time in french while working around their supervisor with no consequences, while other employees, who aren't french background are immediately reminded of the corporate language, whenever they speak in their native language. This is direct discrimination in favour of french speaking people. Either the rule of speaking in corporate language has to apply to all employees or nobody. 3) Even though Thermo Fisher Germany is not producing any pharmaceuticals, they are working for pharmaceuticals companies as a logistic firm. Wages are too low in comparison to pharmaceutical companies, even in comparison to logistic firms such as DHL (the biggest logistic firm in Germany/Europe). 4) Thermo Fisher Germany is outsourcing their employees from multiple different recruitment agencies. Those agencies are not communicating open with their employees before signing contract, about working conditions in Thermo Fisher, such as, you may work in the fridge as a pick and packer or having to take two days crash-course in a total different location, than the location you supposed to go to work. In this case, the cost for transportation is not paid by Thermo Fisher. For example, i had to ride a bike at freezing cold more than one and a half hour at six in the morning, for only getting to the location, where the course take place. 5) Another problem with outsourcing employees from multiple different recruitment agencies is, that the wage are all over the place for the same position, what i found very frustrating. Because i have to do the same job for less money than another employee, who signed a contract with a different recruitment agency. Either, they should outsource their employees from one single recruitment agency or make sure, employees getting the same amount of money for the same position.

pros: Individual contributor co-workers were by and large good people, most operators worked hard and were willing to go above and beyond to help with work that would make their jobs easier or the products they worked on better. Lot of opportunities within the company if you don't mind moving around and want to get into management
cons: Management at the Cincinnati site has fostered a toxic culture of "get it done". Suggestions and plans to train new hires are ignored, quality concerns are addressed unless management decides that the product has to go out, then any and all loopholes will be found. Operators are required to run processes that they don't have any experience with and are instructed to sign off that they have been trained before they are comfortable running the equipment by themselves. It is next to impossible to get promoted within your current group, if you want to move up a level you are all but forced to switch departments. This has led to most departments having a sever lack of tenured employees to act as mentors for people newer to the role. Management, specifically on the Operations side, positions are treated like musical chairs and it is rare to find someone that has held the same management position for more than 2 years, this has led to a culture in which new managers are concerned only with hitting their own metrics to look good for a future promotion and disincentives making their departments better. It takes an unacceptable amount of time to fill a position with external candidates. Because of this, when a critical role becomes vacant, that role is filled with an employee scavenged from another department and that persons role is left open for months. The site currently fills most of it's supervisor and engineering roles with graduating co-ops that they pay far below market value.

The "flexible" work policy is a joke. Every department is different under CCG and people are starting to point fingers on who is in the office and when. It's creating a toxic work environment. 

Michael Dubose wants to "Graingerize" ThermoFisher Scientific by bringing his former people in and its becoming evident. 

The work as Sales Support Representative is essentially a CSR with a brain. You push orders, do sales duties when your assigned territory reps are out in the field. I never felt like my job was secure and could be eliminated at anytime.

job_title: Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
If you want to get into industry, working as a sales rep for this company is your best ticket in. CCG sales is the largest outsourcing of talent in this company meaning if you don't like what you are doing, you are able to move around to different areas.
Great benefits (insurance, retirement, PTO), enjoy my co-workers (for the most apart, there is always that one person)
Upper management is decently nice and respectful towards the employees.
cons: In sales, your commission is based on your margin. Margin is determined from how many orders have shipped. If you have a million dollars in sales but they are all backordered and haven't shipped, this does not reflect in your margin therefore you get no commission. I understand why this is the case (customers can return/cancel orders thus margin has to come from shipped order) but it sucks that you get pay taken away from something you can't control....

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
You'll find both the location and building nice. The job itself seems to be decent, but training is quasi non-existent, not sure if this is due to COVID and the fact that most of the people work remotely. If you're a self-learner that's great, but if you're not and need clear and straight structure for training, it becomes difficult to navigate the right resources.
Huge lack of diversity at this location, and the feeling of competition is astounding making the work environment quite toxic.
Have to constantly walk on eggshells with other scientists and/or staff scientists, and managers/supervisors from other departments as they will literally snitch on you if you ever do or say something that is not to their liking. Management will hardly stand their ground, keep everything on the hush in order to not represent you, they'll literally throw you under the bus and accuse you of wrong doing instead.
This might be a good first experience in the field if you're fresh out of school but don't be fooled, this location has the highest staff turnover.
cons: Everyone working at this location for 20+ years need to realize that this is now Thermo Fisher and not One Lambda anymore. All the nit-pick and negativity is really just adding to the constant stressors, pushing good and valuable employees to transfer to different departments, or to just quit.

job_title: Global Site Services Specialist in Highland Heights, KY
pros:
The ability to work remote most of the month.
Huge cash bonuses (500$) for every 4 hours of time worked during COVID-19.
These have yet to resurface. looks good on a resume if you can last long enough
cons:
The workload is enormous compared to the pay which lands under 20hr for at least the first year.
Training has no structure to it and isn't streamlined. The team is not equally being trained the same way. Information is often withheld for some employees but others are given extra amounts of training. There isn't much by way of learning material for the database you need to learn (Preclarus) and is exclusive to the company so it's really up to them how well you do.
They don't explain much about your job title till after you take the position. It's starts out similar to data entry. The company gives you the impression that's all you will be doing until a year passes and you have been "trained" or "delegated" yet another responsibility every other week with no end in sight 
They are trying to use the GSS team as a call center when they don't have one. The sites are dependent on us for clinical testing results yet you are forced to answer the phone between 2-6 times an hour in addition to your 40hts worth of data corrections and updates.
They literally lied to me telling me my performance was just fine. Then out of the blue it wasn't yet no reason could be furnished as to why.

review_title: They are trying to find their way?
job_title: Quality Control Analyst in Lexington, MA
pros: There are some great people to work with, and they do give some flexible time-off benefits. Supervisors (in most of the groups) are very understanding and will work with you and as hard as you do.
cons: Management is severely misplaced, most not having experience in this field but hired due to having a high level degree. A lot of miscommunications occur with having too many cooks. It doesn't help that with higher -up people not understanding the work and processes that occur in a Biotech company, which leads to a lot of unnecessary processes, instruments, and programs being used. I know it is still in start-up but I can see there being problems for a while until they get their bearings straight. Also, they have one recruiter that is notorious (everyone in the branch know and hate him, even supervisors and managers. A lot of them will go behind his back to the recruiting manager to work their own offers for people they want, as they have learned why it is hard to fill open spots) for horrible offers, while lying about compensation during the interview process, and when the offer comes it is way less than hat was agreed upon or the range implied. At the moment there is a departure of about an employee every other week from my branch and never from manufacturing. I have learned that they are, probably, the only group that is fair with compensation and responsibilities.

pros: Bar is pretty low if you want to be lazy.
cons:
Dead end with poor work life balance.

Resources are given to favorites instead of where needed. Because of this a lot of inexperienced people end up wasting double what someone with experience would use. Based on how they spend and what they produce I would predict that this site will collapse on itself within five years.

Culture is poor. Not uncommon to see directors running office to office spreading gossip. Site culture is to speak poorly of other groups and sites openly.

Full of people that have been here for 15+ years and havent changed, so you're still doing science that's 15 years old despite the field moving on. NPIs aren't novel and people are still hung up on launches from 10 years ago.

Pay is poor. Benefits not up to snuff. HR doesn't exist on site. That could be a pro as they've also been there 15 years and are there for management only.

review_title: Satisfying job at a company that aligns with my personal values
job_title: Staff Program Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
The team at the Austin site is part of the reason I have stayed at this job for well over 10 years. I get to work with a delightful team, brilliant people, and I feel satisfaction knowing my work is helping people. The site has grown exponentially over the last 2 years but it has still maintained that "small site" feel. The teams get together for potlucks, we enjoy parties when we launch new products or have big wins, and I genuinely enjoy working alongside these people. 

I'm proud to work for a company that puts great emphasis on an inclusive environment. There is a fairly diverse team at the Austin site, and really the same is true globally. I enjoy working at a place that appreciates diverse perspectives.

Thermo values work/life balance and the flexibility in my schedule is a great benefit. I like working almost exclusively from home while still providing increased productivity compared to when I was driving on-site everyday. 

The company has given regular bonuses, in addition to the annual bonus, frequently over the last 2 years in particular. Thermo puts a lot of effort into supporting employee retention. I feel like I can grow my career here over many decades and I feel supported when I express interest in learning something new or exploring a new role outside my own. It's obvious they would rather retain employees and allow them to move departments/divisions/functions than risk letting bored employees find new challenges elsewhere.

Benefits are decent.
cons:
The Texas state labor laws are not really in favor of workers, and I resent the fact that the same perks observed by California residents are not observed by Texas residents. Things like not being able to carry over our time off year to year can be awful. 

Sometimes I feel like the company is too big to function. It can be a maze to navigate the right person to contact or process to use. Some of the systems are aging or too many different systems have been mashed together once new companies are acquired, which can make some tasks difficult to manage.

Historically I have felt underpaid. But in recent months my manager and Thermo as a whole, have done a lot in that area to make me stay. Not necessarily a "con" any longer.

For a multi-billion dollar company they couldn't even purchase new equipment, we use ancient instruments to QC finished goods for customers using way more advanced machinery. I once asked if a piece of equipment that was broken could still be used for sterile techniques and the response was "we don't have anther quality inspection for 10 months so we can use it for that long". I loved doing the work it was just the people were the problems.

Simply for having institutional knowledge you could be looked at as some sort of "threat" to the new regime.

Middle managers practice nepotism to an extent i have never seen in my many years as a creative professional.... this extends into the HR department that simply sweeps any unwanted "bad press" under the rug at a local level.

review_title: 5 years later - a great career choice
pros:
This is a company that has longevity and stability.

The senior leadership will give bonuses to all colleagues when the corporation does really well. From 2020 until now, the company has issued 6 weeks of bonus pay to all everyone but the most senior leaders (who I assume get paid plenty). I'm not expecting that to continue forever, but it's great that they are comfortable sharing part of the wealth.

You can make a career here by applying for different roles both at a local site and across the global Thermo Fisher Community. There is opportunity for upward trajectory.

The Engineering Department is never boring. You learn something new every day. Often the new thing to learn starts with "What is that and what on earth does it do?"
cons:
Like most large corporations, you can feel like a number sometimes.

Pay is fair compared to the overall market. There is an aspect of trading a higher salary for job security.

Communications from the top tends to be geared towards personnel who have ready access to a computer or company issued mobile phone. It can be challenging to get the CEO's guidance to colleagues who do not have these things: like production and warehouse personnel.
